page.title: 17A Typical Day in Solihull.
page.content: Most mornings the atmosphere is one of chaos in my house. Daddy, the head of the family, usually cannot find his keys, or a button on his shirt is missing. The telephone rings and, dropping the cornflakes packet, my mother runs to answer it. Usually a lady is ringing to ask Mummy to work in one of the units for impaired hearing schools. Sometimes one of Daddy's friends wants a lift to work. The radios in the house are blaring B.R.M.B., Radio 4 or Radio 3. A loud drone comes from Daddy's razor. We all get dressed for school and are taken over the road. At 4.10pm. I arrive home from school, which is in Solihull. I eat tea and then after listening to the Archers on the radio I have my bath and go to bed.
